trial_identification.scientifictitle: Does binocular vision training enhance literacy among primary school children with poor reading?

conditions.healthcondition: Poor reading due to dyslexia or other conditions but excluding poor reading due to major intellectual disability.

interventions.interventions:
There are three intervention groups all with some efficacy. Interventions A and B will each be compared to C.
A. visual predominant/phonological training, 10 weeks ( one hour per week face to face, 6 hours a week homework) B.phonological predominant/visual training , 10 weeks( one hour per week face to face, 6 hours a week homework)
interventions.comparator: C. parent-child educational program, 10 weeks (comparison intervention)( no face to face, 7 hours a week homework)

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline, 10 weeks and 26 weeks

primaryOutcome.outcome: Rate of reading test. Woodcock Reading Mastery Test - Revised: - Passage comprehension - Letter identification - Word identification - Word attack
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline, 10 weeks and 26 weeks

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Visual acuity (3m LogMAR) *Binocular *Monocular Stereotest Lang test Worth 4 dot Near point of convergence *Objective *Subjective Accommodative facility Near vision
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Vision, to be measured at baseline, 10 weeks and 26 weeks.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Developmental Eye Movement (DEM) test d2 Test of Attention Copying test error rate per 100 words Visual attention span
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Visual Processing, to be measured at baseline, 10 weeks and 26 weeks.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Conner Parent Rating Score Revised, short form Conner Teacher Rating Score Revised, short form
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Attention Defict Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), to be measured at baseline, 10 weeks and 26 weeks.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Children in the lowest decile of literacy according to Grade 3 national literacy and numeracy tests who also have poor stereovision on screening assessment. Children must reside in Southern Tasmania (telephone 0362).

trial_design.sequence: Permuted block randomisation. Block sizes are not variable

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Menzies Research Institute, University of Tasmania

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Faculty of Education, University of Tasmania
Deapartment of Pediatrics and Child Health, University of Tasmania

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Five to ten percent of primary school children fail to learn to read at the standard expected from their intelligence and educational and cultural background. This condition is known as dyslexia.
In 2005-2006, a dyslexia project is being conducted in participating Southern Tasmanian schools. Past work has shown that some children with normal intelligence have reading problems because of problems with coordinating both eyes to read visual images. The project aims to screen for vision coordination problems among children with low literacy. It is not currently known what proportion of children who have difficulty reading have vision problems in relation to scanning text with both eyes working together.
The main aim of the Literacy Pathways Project is:
To assess how children may benefit from different programs to assist them with reading. Each program contains a mixture of activities that are based on past work indicating that they have benefited some children with reading problems. The relative importance of the different components within or between the programs is currently not known and is the subject of the educational trial.
Participants are unaware of the intervention status and commercial names of the reading programs in the study. The programs are referred to as the orange, yellow or green program. Participants are not aware of the content of the other programs. The people conducting the assessments are blind to intervention status.
Analysis - The true group allocation will be removed for the analysis and only added back in at the end. That is, the analyst will only analyse the data being aware of the orange, yellow or green categories but not the intervention status associated with each.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Northern Tasmanian Health and Medical Human Research Ethics Committee
